newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary welcomes Moscow decision to talk with NATO.
newsitem.headline: Hungary welcomes Moscow decision to talk with NATO.

text.p: Hungary on Wednesday welcomed Russia's decision to open talks with NATO on a special relationship despite its deep hostility to alliance plans to expand eastwards.

"Russia still opposes the enlargement of NATO," defence ministry state secretary Istvan Gyarmati told Hungarian television. "But it will have to accept it and to negotiate on this basis its future relations with an enlarged NATO."

In a major change of policy, Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov told his 16 NATO counterparts in Brussels on Wednesday that Moscow was ready to enter into dialogue on a new security partnership between the former Cold War foes.
Hungarian Foreign Minister Laszlo Kovacs told Hungarian television that developments in Brussels led him to believe that Hungary would be invited to join NATO early in 1999.
"Hungary's accession can be relatively clearly calculated for spring 1999," he said. "That is when the first group of new members will be officially accepted."
Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic are the favourites to be invited to join out of a total of 11 countries now clamouring at NATO's door.
